7.48.text:
This is a film about Stoicism and why you
need more of it in your life - because, as

12.01.text: people seldom tell you, but we will, quietly...

17.50.text:
Stoicism was a philosophy that flourished
for 480 years in Ancient Greece and Rome,

22.53.text:
and was popular with everyone from slaves
to the aristocracy: because - unlike so much

27.02.text:
philosophy, it was helpful, helpful when we
panic, want to give up, despair and rage at existence.

33.13.text:
We still honour this philosophy whenever we
think of someone as brave and - without perhaps

40.40.text:
There are two great philosophers of Stoicism.
The first is the Roman writer and tutor to

44.93.text: Nero, Seneca. He lived between AD 4 and AD 65

48.84.text:
That's right, 'tutor to Nero'. The infamous
dictator who slept with his own mother, raped

53.38.text:
young boys and, just because he felt like
it, asked his old tutor - Seneca - to commit

57.49.text:
suicide in front of his own family.
And our other guide to Stoicism is

61.10.text:
the kind and magnanimous Roman Emperor Marcus
Aurelius [AD 121 to 180], who was forced to

66.59.text:
spend most of his reign on the edges of the
Empire, fighting off invincible Germanic hordes,

71.37.text:
but found time to write one of the greatest
works of philosophy, the Meditations

77.15.text:
There are two problems stoicism can help us
with in particular.

82.42.text:
When you're feeling anxious about something,
most people are maddening. They believe it

85.94.text:
is their duty to 'cheer you up'. However intelligent
they might otherwise be, they say things like:

93.38.text:
The stoics were appalled. They hated any kind
of consolation that aims to give the listener

99.31.text:
Hope is the opium of the emotions and must
be stamped out conclusively for a person to

103.96.text: stand any chance of inner peace.

106.57.text:
Because hope only lifts one higher for the
eventual fall.

110.52.text:
The Stoics advised us to take a different
path. To be calm, one has to tell oneself

114.78.text:
something very dark:
It will be terrible!

117.38.text: I might have to go to prison. The lump really could be malign.

120.36.text:
I probably will be fired and humiliated.
My friends almost certainly will succeed.

124.76.text:
BUT, a huge consoling Stoic BUT, one must
keep in mind that one will, nevertheless,

131.77.text:
OK because in the end, as Marcus Aurelius
said: 'We are each of us stronger than we think'

136.90.text: Prison won't be fun, nor will losing one's job

139.60.text:
or being made a laughing stock... but
one will get through it. Stoicism emboldens

144.33.text: us against the worst fate can throw at us.

147.19.text:
And if you really really can't take it, suicide
is always an option.

152.57.text:
Here is Seneca:
'Can you no longer see a road to freedom?

155.87.text:
It's right in front of you. You need only
turn over your wrists'.

160.01.text:
To build up an impression of one's own resilience,
the Stoics suggested one regularly rehearse

166.01.text:
For example, twice a year, one should take
off one's smart clothes, get into some dirty rags,

170.52.text:
sleep on a rug in the kitchen floor
and eat only stale bread and rainwater from

174.64.text:
an animal's bowl - and thereby make an amazing
discovery.

178.47.text:
As Marcus Aurelius put it:
ALMOST NOTHING MATERIAL IS NEEDED FOR A HAPPY LIFE

182.51.text: FOR HE WHO HAS UNDERSTOOD EXISTENCE

186.53.text:
Another subject of interest to the Stoics
was ANGER

189.30.text: Romans were a bad tempered lot.

191.53.text:
The Stoics wanted to calm them down but they
did so by an unusual route: by intellectual argument.

196.42.text:
They proposed that getting angry
isn't something you do by nature, because

200.81.text:
you have a Latin temper or are somehow inherently
hot blooded.

204.25.text:
It's the result of being stupid, of having
the wrong ideas about life.

209.11.text:
Anger stems when misplaced hope smashes into
unforeseen reality. We don’t shout every

214.43.text:
time something bad happens to us, only when
it is bad and UNEXPECTED

219.70.text:
For example, you'd never shout just because
it started raining - even though rain can

223.65.text:
be horrible, because you've learnt to expect
rain.

226.83.text:
The same should apply to everything. Don't
only expect rain, expect betrayal, infamy,

231.58.text: sadism, theft, humiliation, lust, greed, spite...

235.03.text:
One will stop being so angry when one learns
the true facts of the misery of life.

240.72.text:
The wise person should aim to reach a state
where simply nothing could suddenly disturb their peace of mind.

245.90.text:
Every tragedy should
already be priced in.

248.99.text:
We're going to leave you with the most beautiful
remark that Seneca made just as Nero's guards

253.31.text: were grabbing him and shoving him to a bathroom where he was meant to take a sharp knife and kill himself.

257.60.text: His wife Paulina and two children were panicking, weeping, clinging to his cloaks.

262.29.text: But he turned to them, pulled a weary smile at them, and simply said:

266.35.text:
WHAT NEED IS THERE TO WEEP OVER PARTS OF LIFE?
THE WHOLE OF IT CALLS FOR TEARS.

272.51.text: We have much to learn from the Stoics.
